--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:

> I'm still not sure if you've grasped my main point here. Ok so 
sometimes 
> a new connection appears and it immediately increases the fitness 
of a 
> genome - good. But whenever a neuron is added it can *never* be 
> immediately beneficial because NEAT adds them in such a way as to 
make 
> them equivalent to the connection that was split. 


Colin, I pretty much agree with your main point, but this point is 
technically not correct.  Adding a node *does* slightly change a 
connection, because it changes it from linear to nonlinear, since a 
sigmoid (in the new node) is nonlinear.  Even a steepened sigmoid is 
not equivalent to a line.  And that nonlinearity may in some cases 
actually increase fitness on its own.

ken
